title: tf.clip_by_global_norm() returns zero tensors if the norm is infinity
body_html:
I think this should return NaN tensors instead of zero tensors to signal an error. Users expect tf.clip_by_global_norm() to return tensors unaltered or with global norm matching the threshold passed into the function. This invariant is violated by returning zero tensors.

This is caused by 1.0 / use_norm which is zero for an infinite norm in clip_ops.py:

scale = clip_norm * math_ops.minimum(
        1.0 / use_norm,
        constant_op.constant(1.0, dtype=use_norm.dtype) / clip_norm)

body:
I think this should return NaN tensors instead of zero tensors to signal an error. Users expect `tf.clip_by_global_norm()` to return tensors unaltered or with global norm matching the threshold passed into the function. This invariant is violated by returning zero tensors.

This is caused by `1.0 / use_norm` which is zero for an infinite norm in [clip_ops.py](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/25c197e02393bd44f50079945409009dd4d434f8/tensorflow/python/ops/clip_ops.py#L257):

```python
scale = clip_norm * math_ops.minimum(
        1.0 / use_norm,
        constant_op.constant(1.0, dtype=use_norm.dtype) / clip_norm)
```
